chunks.text: And what I thought I would take you through is some ideas that at the beginning of the talk, some things I feel pretty strongly about, and then some things at the end which are kind of way, way at the edge of what we know, and basically speculation that I think is useful nevertheless Okay, so here are four things I'm going to try to talk about very quickly First of all, I'm going to address this issue of biology, solving problems at all levels, in all kinds of problem spaces, and argue that genomes are not drivers, if anything, they are more like libraries of affordances, and that evolution makes problem solving agents, not solutions to specific problems I will not have time to talk about this Normally, if I give a long talk, I actually show how we go about communicating with the agential material that underlies life, because this is where we have most of our data Then what I will talk about is give some thoughts about basically the fact that the architecture of life is fundamentally creative because it is dealing with an unreliable substrate, and that this gives rise to a really powerful intelligence ratchet And towards the end, if we have time, I'll talk about some recent ideas about shifting the perspective of agents versus data and how the notion of Platonic space can be actually useful for research
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the role of genomes in biology, viewing them as libraries of affordances rather than drivers. They also explore the concept of biology as a problem-solving agent, the communication with the agential material that underlies life, and the idea of life's architecture being fundamentally creative due to its interaction with an unreliable substrate. Towards the end, the speaker plans to discuss the perspective of agents versus data and the potential utility of Platonic space in research.

chunks.text: So what I'm interested in is to address something that I think we have, which is a degree of mind blindness And it's an analogy You can think about this as the electromagnetic spectrum It used to be back in the day that things that happen when you wave magnets around, light, X rays, all of those things were thought to be very, very different things Actually, could we mute somebody Somebody's Yep, there we go Thank you And, and something, something really interesting happened when we ended up with a proper theory of electromagnetism, which is that first of all, phenomena that were thought to be extremely different turned out to be manifestations of the same thing And so we, we, we have an idea for how they relate to each other And it allowed a technology to be made that enables us to detect and interact with and make use of all kinds of things that were completely inaccessible to us with our natural set of senses And so I think something like that is happening with cognition, where evolution has given us some firmware that enables us to recognize certain extremely narrow range of kinds of minds And I think we need to develop theory and that will lead to practical tools to enable us to recognize, create, and ethically relate to a very wide, diverse set of intelligences, regardless of how they got here or what they're made of And so we're interested in my group, in understanding how to relate to all of these kinds of weird things And in particular very important to move experimental work forward
chunks.content_summary: Michael Levin discusses the analogy between the electromagnetic spectrum and cognition, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive theory to understand diverse intelligences. He highlights the importance of developing practical tools to recognize, create, and ethically relate to a wide range of intelligences, regardless of their origin or composition.

chunks.text: So I like philosophical ideas that end up being computational models and then end up being applications and eventually therapeutics And this is why part of the lab does birth defects, regenerative medicine, cancer and so on, because then we know we're on the right track And in particular, again, what I don't have time to do today, but what I do, I've just sort of made a recent talk about All of this is similar to what happened to different kinds of numbers where we slowly, with certain kinds of schisms and people sort of freaking out when they discover certain new kinds of numbers we've kind of enlarged Even though some of these sets are infinite, we've discovered novel degrees of infinity and new kinds of numbers I think the same thing is happening and going to happen more with the sets of cognitive agents that are out there And so we all can recognize this, some of us are okay with this, or even this
secondary_topics: Discovery of new kinds of numbers
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the importance of computational models derived from philosophical ideas in understanding and treating various biological conditions such as birth defects and cancer. The speaker also draws a parallel between the discovery of new kinds of numbers and the potential for discovering new cognitive agents.

chunks.text: But actually it gets really weird And this, I'm not prepared to talk much We could touch on it, but I'm not prepared to talk much about this today But we can certainly talk about this and the infinity of sentient forms I think once we understand what we're looking at is getting bigger and bigger and bigger and we can think about for each of these things what is needed to be able to recognize these things And then what does it break for our assumptions and then how do we do something useful Okay, so the first section here is I'm just going to show you a little bit of biology and this idea that what we call life are systems that self assemble into a multi scale competency architecture where every level has agendas and certain capabilities which explores problem spaces by aligning its parts towards larger and more diverse goals
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of self-assembly in biological systems, which form a multi-scale competency architecture. Each level of this architecture has its own capabilities and agendas, which allows the system to explore problem spaces by aligning its parts towards larger and more diverse goals.

chunks.text: This is the journey that each of us takes from physics and chemistry which describe this quiescent oocyte That's how we all start life eventually, through this slow, gradual, continuous process No magic lightning flashes that suddenly push us into the realm of psychology and so on Eventually we end up being something like this This is what we're made of These are single cells They're extremely I mean this is a free living organism But you can see in a single cell, no brain, no nervous system, it has all kinds of capacities to pursue its own tiny little goals And then life normally goes this way It can take some twists and turns, it can have a breakdown of Multicellularity, a kind of dissociative identity disorder of the collective intelligence that gives rise to cancer It can also, with our help, go into new directions, such as these anthrobots, which can continue life even after a patient has died And we can talk about all that And what fundamentally happens to bring us into the world is alignment and a kind of dynamic storytelling And what I mean by that is that when we look at an embryo, and there may be, let's say at an early stage, it's a sheet of 100,000 cells Why do we look at that and we say there's one embryo, what is there one of If there's 100,000 cells, what's there one of Well, what there's one of is a particular model, a commitment to travel in anatomical space to a particular location that describes whatever it is that's being built A human, a giraffe, snake, whatever And all of the cells are committed to this one story of what it is that they're building
chunks.content_summary: The presentation discusses the journey of life from a single cell to a complex organism, emphasizing the role of bioelectricity and cellular intelligence. It also explores the concept of multicellularity, its breakdown leading to cancer, and the potential of anthrobots in continuing life after death.

chunks.text: And all of the cells are committed to this one story of what it is that they're building And the fact that they're all committed to the same story and reliably make that journey together is what allows us to call it one embryo But if you were to, and I used to do this in grad school with duck embryos, you take a little needle and you put some scratches into this blastoderm Each one of these little islands will align within itself because it can't feel the others and self organize into a new embryo And you get multiples, twins, triplets, quadruplets and so on, which may or may not then heal up and reattach
chunks.content_summary: The presentation discusses the concept of cellular commitment in embryonic development and how cells self-organize to form an embryo. It also explores experimental manipulation of duck embryos, resulting in the creation of multiple embryos (twins, triplets, quadruplets) from a single blastoderm.

chunks.text: But in the meantime, you have multiple individuals So the question is, how many selves are present in an embryo is not at all obvious It's not nailed down by the genetics It's a self organizing process that leads to the creation of anywhere from, I shouldn't say creation, the manifestation of anywhere from zero to half a dozen or more individuals And the capacity of this excitable medium is not really clear, much like it's not really clear in the brain at all how many actual individuals fit into a particular amount of real estate in the brain And we can, we can talk about that
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complex nature of embryonic development, emphasizing that it is not solely dictated by genetics, but rather a self-organizing process. The capacity of this 'excitable medium' is compared to the unclear capacity of the brain to accommodate individuals.

chunks.text: So what you have here is then, is then alignment, both physical and functional, to a particular model of navigation of that space Like any good collective intelligence, or any intelligence really, it can be We can think about how reliably it does its job Here are acorns, they make these oak leaves We think that, okay, this is what the oak genome knows how to do, is direct the formation of exactly this pattern It's incredibly reliable They're very good at doing their job, these cells But of course it's hackable For example, this is an example of a non human bioengineer This little wasp that comes around and deposits some signals, a kind of bioprompting that causes these cells to build something completely different Right
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of collective intelligence in biological systems, using the example of oak leaf formation directed by the oak genome. They also introduce the idea of 'bioprompting', where external signals can manipulate cellular function, as demonstrated by a wasp altering the development of a leaf.

chunks.text: So you'd have no idea that these flat green things were actually capable of building something like this or something like this And there are lots of examples that I could show you how life hacks each itself and each other, and how we are learning to do it One of the most interesting interfaces to this collective intelligence, much like in the brain So what is it in the brain It's bioelectricity or AKA electrophysiology, But that's actually extremely ancient It was used as a cognitive glue by evolution long before brains and muscles appeared And so we now have ways to manipulate, to observe it and manipulate it And just to show you a couple of things, because the visuals are cool, this is an early frog embryo putting its face together And you can see that the colors are voltage, the colors are the different voltages of the cells
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of bioelectricity or electrophysiology, which is an ancient mechanism used by evolution as a cognitive glue before the appearance of brains and muscles. They also mention the ability to observe and manipulate this bioelectricity, using the example of a frog embryo developing its face, where different colors represent different cellular voltages.

chunks.text: This is one frame What you're seeing here is you're reading out the memories inside the collective intelligence that's navigating that anatomical space This is the memory, this is the face So here's where the mouth is going to go, here's where the right eye is going to be Here are the placodes This is what guides the downstream gene expression and the anatomy to form a proper face This is how This, when you ask how do the cells know what to do This is how they know what to do This is their memory And that bioelectric pattern is not just for bundling together cells to form a single embryo It actually connects multiple embryos together
chunks.content_summary: The speaker, Michael Levin, discusses the concept of bioelectricity and its role in embryonic development. He suggests that cells have a form of 'memory' that guides their behavior and gene expression, ultimately determining the formation of anatomical structures such as the face.

chunks.text: So it's a multi scale kind of phenomenon If I poke this guy here, all of his friends, each one of these things is a separate embryo It's a separate frog embryo Each one of them finds out about it You can poke this one here Within some minutes they all find out about it And here you can see some cells doing their thing So once you start to read these, it's basically think of neural decoding, think of trying to read the electrophysiology of the brain and extract memories and preferences and so on We can do the same thing in morphogenesis and we can start to manipulate it
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the multiscale phenomena of embryonic development, particularly in frogs. They highlight the interconnectedness of cells and the potential for manipulating morphogenesis through understanding and decoding the bioelectric signals within the embryo.

chunks.text: So while the normal flatworm has a very clear memory that it needs one head and one tail, so that when you cut it into pieces, every piece makes one head and one tail We can change that, we can incept false memories into these things using optogenetics and pharmacology and various other means And so now you can say, no, actually And of course this is still messy, we're still working this out, but you can say no, actually, you should have two heads And it's a perfectly normal one headed animal, right There he is with the wrong internal representation of what a correct planarian should look like It's a latent memory In fact, it's a counterfactual because it's not true Right now, right now he has one head
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the ability to manipulate the regenerative process in flatworms, specifically altering their inherent 'memory' of their body plan to induce the formation of two heads. This is achieved through techniques such as optogenetics and pharmacology.

chunks.text: But what happens is if you cut him, if you cut the tail, the head and the tail, that fragment is actually going to give rise to, we had an animal And I now have to tell people, this is not AI, this is not, you know, Photoshop These are real, real results And what happens is because this is what enables the collective to know what to build and when to stop So you can, you can read out these pattern memories if you continue to cut these two headed animals that the memory holds It's a bioelectric memory It is not controlled by the genetics The genetics are totally wild type Nothing has changed Changes in the genome sequencing the genome will not tell you that these things have two heads It will also not tell you that the whole lineage will have two heads because you can keep cutting them And in fact, when they reproduce, they cut themselves in half on their own and then they regenerate They will continue to be two headed Here's a video You can see what these guys are doing
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses an experiment where an animal's tail and head are cut, leading to regeneration due to bioelectric memory, not genetics. This memory allows the animal to keep regenerating as a two-headed creature, even when reproducing by splitting in half.

chunks.text: So what we're seeing here is that there are a variety of computational systems at all levels of organization And I don't have time to talk about all the cool things that the genetic networks are doing They can learn too You don't even need cells, just the molecular networks alone have six different kinds of memory, including Pavlovian conditioning But all of these things work together and they solve problems in various spaces And as I mentioned before, we are tuned to recognize medium sized objects moving at medium speeds in three dimensional space And so crows and primates and maybe a whale or an octopus, we can sort of get that
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complexity of computational systems in biology, focusing on the capabilities of genetic networks. These networks, even at the molecular level, are capable of learning and memory, including Pavlovian conditioning. The speaker also touches on the ability of certain animals to perceive medium-sized objects moving in three-dimensional space.

chunks.text: But what biology is teaching us is, is that embodiment is really not what we think So when people say that a various kinds of AIs are not embodied because they don't roll around the room on wheels and they don't walk around that I, I think that's actually not, not the right way to think about it at all Because there's lots of perception, action loops and goal directedness and intelligence that take place in spaces that we cannot see So your cells and your tissues are navigating a high dimensional space of possible gene expressions They're navigating a space of physiological states And of course what we study is morphous space, okay
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of embodiment in biology, suggesting it is not limited to physical movement or presence. They highlight that cells and tissues navigate a high-dimensional space of possible gene expressions and physiological states, which is an aspect of intelligence not visible to the naked eye.

chunks.text: So the space of possible anatomical configurations And they don't just roll down hills and automatically sort of do the same thing every single time They are really navigating with some amazing capabilities The kind of problem solving that they do is, is astounding I'm just going to show you two examples We could talk about this for hours And I think really important for us to understand in order to make real artificial intelligence and things like that So here's just one example You take this planaria, these flatworms, you put them in a solution of barium chloride Barium is a non specific potassium channel blocker It makes their cells very unhappy Their heads explode Literally over the next 24 hours, they're heads explode
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complex problem-solving capabilities of organisms, specifically planaria (flatworms), and how understanding these can contribute to the development of artificial intelligence. An experiment is mentioned where planaria are exposed to barium chloride, a potassium channel blocker, resulting in a dramatic cellular response.

chunks.text: But if you leave them in the barium, what happens is that a little while later they will make a new head And the new head is completely fine with barium, no problem It's barium adapted When you check what is different about the original head and the barium adapted head, you find that it's, it's only, it's, it's less than a dozen genes that are different And the trick is that these guys, planaria, have never seen barium either These worms, nor in their evolutionary history, there's never been selection for knowing what to do when you get hit with barium
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses an experiment where planaria regenerate a new head after exposure to barium. The new head is adapted to barium, with less than a dozen genes differing from the original. This adaptation is remarkable as planaria have no evolutionary history of barium exposure.

chunks.text: So just think about this, this problem You've got an, you've got an extreme physiological stressor You have on the order of 20,000 control knobs that you can, that you can, that you can twist So like a Moravic bush, you know, with, with, with an incredible number of effectors, which of these genes do you turn on enough to solve a novel, a novel stressor It's kind of like being in a nuclear reactor control room The thing's melting down And unless you know exactly how it works, unless you have a model of your own apparatus, what you don't have time to do is to start flipping switches randomly to see if life gets better because you'll be dead And there's no time for that
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complexity of managing physiological stressors, comparing it to controlling a nuclear reactor. They emphasize the importance of understanding the system (i.e., the body's bioelectric mechanisms) to effectively regulate genes and respond to stressors, rather than randomly 'flipping switches'.

chunks.text: So we need to understand how these living systems actually solve novel problems That they haven't seen before This is maybe my favorite example of all time This is a cross section through the kidney tubule of a salamander So normally 8 to 10 cells that make this thing up What you can do is you can make these newts with more copies of their genetic material So when you have more copies of their genetic material, so instead of 2N chromosomes, you can have 4N, 5N, 6N and so on When you do this, the cells get bigger, but the newt stays the same size Well, how can that be Well, it's because the cell, there's actually few fewer cells that make up the same structure The cells are bigger, but there's less of them Okay And then when you make the cells truly gigantic, what you find is that one cell will bend around itself like this and leave a space in the middle, same structure
chunks.content_summary: The presentation discusses how living systems, specifically the kidney tubule cells of a salamander, adapt to changes in genetic material. By increasing the number of chromosome copies, cells become larger but fewer in number, maintaining the same overall structure. When cells become extremely large, they can bend around themselves to maintain the same structure.

chunks.text: Now here are a couple of amazing parts First of all, this is a completely different molecular mechanism So instead of cell to cell communication and tubulogenesis, here, this is cytoskeletal bending So, so what the system is doing is what you would do on an IQ test You use various tools at your disposal to get to the, to solve the problem, to get to the same goal in novel ways beyond what you would normally do Right It's creative use of the tools that you already have And think about what this means from the perspective of the system You come into the world, what can you count on Well, you can't count on your environment, we all know that
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses a unique molecular mechanism involving cytoskeletal bending, contrasting it with traditional cell to cell communication and tubulogenesis. The speaker also emphasizes the system's ability to use existing tools creatively to solve problems and adapt to varying environments.

chunks.text: But you also apparently can't You don't know how many copies of your genetic material you're going to have You don't know how big your cells are going to be You don't know how many cells you're going to have But you still have to make that newt And in a minute I'm going to show you you can actually make other things But you try really hard to make that newt, despite the fact that you can't even rely on your own parts, never mind the environment You can't even assume that your parts are what they are So here, for the next couple minutes, I just want to talk about this That unlike most of the things we program, life really operates with a, with a poly computing architecture where you are free to reinterpret all the messages that you have, and those are genetic messages from the past Everything you have is up for interpretation Because your substrate is unreliable You cannot afford to care too much about what your ancestors thought that your genes mean or what your past self thinks that Your memories meant you have to reinterpret all this stuff from scratch
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the unpredictability of biological development, emphasizing the variability in genetic material, cell size, and cell quantity. They introduce the concept of a poly computing architecture in life, where genetic messages and memories are open to reinterpretation due to the unreliability of the biological substrate.

chunks.text: Let me just show you a couple of examples of how this looks on three scales On the evolutionary scale, the developmental scale and the cognitive scale One of the things that I like to think about is caterpillars and butterflies Caterpillars are this kind of soft bodied creature with a controller suitable for soft body motion, and they crawl around and they eat leaves They have to turn into this thing that lives in the three dimensional world and it forms, flies around, and it's a hard bodied creature and it needs a completely different controller for that And so in the meantime, what it does is it basically liquefies its brain, kills most of the cells, breaks most of the connections, and then eventually rebuilds a new butterfly brain Okay, so what is known is that if you train the caterpillar to, let's say, eat leaves when it sees a particular colored disc, it's known that butterflies actually retain this information
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the transformation of caterpillars into butterflies, emphasizing the drastic changes in physical form, brain structure, and behavior. Despite these changes, butterflies retain information learned as caterpillars, illustrating the continuity of memory through metamorphosis.

chunks.text: So on the surface of it, the crazy thing here to think about is, well, how do you maintain information while you're drastically refactoring the substrate Okay, and so that's a cool question, but there's a better, there's an even more amazing piece to this, which is that the actual memories of the caterpillar are of absolutely no use to the butterfly The butterfly doesn't crawl, it doesn't eat leaves, it wants nectar The memories of the caterpillar, if they were trying to stay intact, would never survive But if they are able to be remapped onto a new architecture, not just carried over, not just persist, but actually change, remap, then they survive into this new embodiment as the creature gains a new life in a higher dimensional space
secondary_topics: New Life in Higher Dimensional Space
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the intriguing process of how a caterpillar's memories are maintained and remapped during its metamorphosis into a butterfly. Despite the drastic changes in physical form and lifestyle, certain memories survive by being remapped onto a new 'architecture'.

chunks.text: So you have here something like the paradox of change, where if you as a biological organism or a lineage, if you stay the same, you will surely die when the circumstances change But if you change to fit those circumstances, in a sense, you, meaning the old you, is still gone How do you persist You cannot persist in place Right That's the, that seems to be the paradox So what I like to think about is this idea that your memories, and these are memories, these are both cognitive memories and genetic memories are just messages from, from your past self
chunks.content_summary: The speaker, Michael Levin, discusses the paradox of change in biological organisms, where adaptation to changing circumstances is necessary for survival, but also results in the loss of the 'old self'. He introduces the concept of cognitive and genetic memories as messages from the past self, contributing to the persistence of the organism.

chunks.text: So what you don't have access to at any given moment in time is the past You have no idea what happened in the past What you have are memory engrams, traces left in your brain and body that were constructed by your past selves They were compressed, they were Generalized, they went through this bottleneck So here are all the stuff that, I mean, all the computer science people will recognize this immediately All the inputs and the different diverse experiences came through They were compressed somehow into these, this very, this very thin substrate which are the engrams that people still fight about what that is
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of memory engrams as traces left in the brain and body by past experiences. They highlight the process of data compression and generalization that these memories undergo, likening it to a bottleneck, and note the ongoing debate about the nature of engrams.

chunks.text: But future you has to decompress them And information was lost here You don't actually know what these memories mean When you find a particular memory molecule or a set of electrical states in your brain, you don't actually know what they mean You have to creatively interpret them And I suspect that while this part can be algorithmic and deductive, this part I don't think can I suspect this is, and I don't exactly know what this is, I'll speculate a little bit at the end, but there's something else going on here which allows, allows those memories to be remapped in a novel context Like every memory, every message from others at the current time, messages from past, you also need to be interpreted And you don't need to really care about what they meant before What you do need to care about is how do I make them adaptive now
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complexity of memory interpretation, emphasizing that understanding the meaning of specific memory molecules or bioelectric states in the brain requires creative interpretation. The speaker also suggests that memories need to be adaptively remapped in new contexts, rather than focusing on their original meanings.

chunks.text: So what the biology is optimizing for is not fidelity of information, it's saliency So you're not trying to keep the caterpillar memories as they are, you're trying to remap them to a new meaning and new functions So the same thing is happening in, so that's the cognitive side, the same thing is happening in the developmental side when you have a genome And I know I didn't have time to go through all these examples, probably you can find some of the stuff in this paper But the idea basically is this, that you come into the world with a certain genome
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of information optimization in biology, emphasizing that the goal is not to maintain the fidelity of information, but to remap it for new meanings and functions. This process is compared to the role of the genome in development.

chunks.text: But now comes the creative process So this is all of past history, this is your genetics Now comes the fun part of, as if, if you're an embryo or a regenerating organ or anything like that, is to say, what do these things mean And in my current environment and given what's going on now, how do I use this information to do something useful And we have lots of examples in biology of this happening I'll show you a couple more now So basically the idea is that you can't over train on what the past was You assume that the hardware is unreliable, meaning you know you're going to get mutated You know that proteins come and go You have no idea exactly how many of anything is in your cell All of that stuff is Very fluid And for this reason, you have to commit to interpreting on the fly And what evolution does is produce systems that are very good at creative interpretation of data
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the dynamic nature of biological systems, emphasizing the importance of genetics and evolution in the development and regeneration of organs. The speaker also highlights the inherent unpredictability and fluidity of biological systems, including mutations and protein dynamics, and the necessity for systems to interpret and adapt to these changes.

chunks.text: First that, that was the case physiologically, then, you know, genetically and developmentally, and then eventually, you know, conventional cognition And again, all of this, all of this is here One of the cool things about it is that this gives rise to an interesting intelligence, ratchet So the more creative interpretation of your genome you do during development, the harder it is for selection to actually know whether your genome was any good or not And we've done simulations of this to show that what happens when you evolve over a competent material like this is that the pressure on the structural genome comes off and all of the work of evolution starts being done on the actual algorithm of, of the creative interpretation of the tools that you have Because with each sort of run through that loop, it becomes harder and harder to select better genomes because you can't see them You can just see the fact that useful phenotypes had appeared And so I think that ratchet started very early on, and it contributes to the amazing, you know, sort of conventional intelligence that we see in the, in the animal world Okay, and so the last part, just, just maybe two, two minutes more, the last part is this When we have these, when the, the systems that I showed you, when I talk about problem solving, what I've, what I've been showing you are systems that can get to their goal by different means
primary_topics: Evolutionary pressure on the structural genome
Intelligence emergence in the animal world
secondary_topics: Simulation of evolution over competent material
Selection difficulty due to creative genome interpretation
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of creative genome interpretation during development, which makes it difficult for selection to evaluate the quality of the genome. This leads to a shift in evolutionary pressure from the structural genome to the algorithm of genome interpretation. The speaker also mentions how this process contributes to the emergence of intelligence in the animal world.

chunks.text: So that's William James's definition of intelligence And there's, there's sort of, they have these competencies The newt will be the same size even if you mess with the genetics or the size of cells or whatever But what happens when you make novel systems Where do their goals come from Because for all of the natural systems, you could say, well, evolution did that Evolution gave you the goal And that's what we normally say Why does this animal look the way it looks Why does it have behaviors that it has Because of selection Eons of selection gave you that goal Okay, what happens in novel systems I'm very interested in where goals come from I don't really think they come from evolution per se And so we wanted a model system that tries to study that aspect of it And so in biology, we like genetics and we like environment, and those are the two things, the two sources of information that we think and so on
primary_topics: Role of evolution in shaping goals
Influence of genetics and environment in biology
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the definition of intelligence and the role of evolution in shaping the goals of biological systems. They express interest in the origins of goals in novel systems, questioning the traditional belief that they come solely from evolution. The influence of genetics and environment in biology is also discussed.

chunks.text: So I'm very interested in this kind of stuff When we make novel beings, whether technological hybrids or biological and cyborgs and augmented Humans, all kinds of weird stuff that is already partially in existence What else I mean, these, you know, these things, these things here don't really necessarily have a history of selection for specific properties Where else are they getting these goals if it's not Where do these patterns come from if it's not selection And by the way, one story I didn't show you is that there is an anatomical space There are these attractors that correspond to different species shapes And we can actually show that the same genetic hardware can actually visit multiple attractors It doesn't have to go to its species specific attractor, but, but they're there And then people will say, well, okay, fine, so these are shaped by evolution
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the creation of biohybrid beings, cyborgs, and augmented humans, questioning how these entities develop specific properties without a history of evolutionary selection. They also mention the concept of anatomical space and species-specific attractors, suggesting that the same genetic hardware can visit multiple attractors.

chunks.text: So what I'm really interested in are patterns that don't have a history and they don't have an explanation in terms of physics And what could that possibly be So, so here's one example This thing is called a Halley plot and there's a million examples I just like these It's called a Hali plot You get it It's a fractal that you get from plotting this very simple formula, this tiny little seed in complex number Z If you unpack, it gives you this And if you slowly change one of these numbers, what you'll get are videos and movies of all this kind of stuff
chunks.content_summary: The speaker is interested in unexplained patterns, using the example of a Halley plot, a fractal derived from a simple formula involving complex numbers. The speaker notes that changing one of these numbers results in dynamic visual changes.

chunks.text: So what's interesting here, and then you can, you can make all sorts of other things clearly clear Complexity doesn't hurt that it's kind of organic looking as well But what's interesting about it is that it does not have, at least to my knowledge, I'm not a mathematician, but to my knowledge it does not have an explanation in physics It does not have an explanation of history It was not evolved, it was not selected Is, it is in some way indexed into by this tiny little, little seed or pointer I don't, I don't think you can call it a compression for reasons we can, we can talk about
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complexity and organic nature of certain structures or phenomena that, to their knowledge, lack a clear explanation in physics or history. They also mention the concept of a 'seed' or 'pointer' that somehow indexes these phenomena, but reject the idea that this could be considered a form of compression.

chunks.text: But, but clearly there are, there are patterns that come from, from at least mathematics that, that do not have the conventional kind of explanation that biological patterns have So how much of this is actually relevant to biology So, so, so biologists hate this idea because they want a nice kind of sparse ontology where you have, you have the physical world and that's it And they don't want any, you know, any, any weird stuff But I think a lot of mathematicians are actually pretty comfortable that what they're doing is exploring a completely different world that is not in fact explained by any fact of Physics, it matters for physics
primary_topics: Ontological Differences between Biology and Mathematics
Role of Physics in Biological and Mathematical Patterns
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the unconventional nature of mathematical patterns in biology, highlighting the ontological differences between the perspectives of biologists and mathematicians. The role of physics in explaining these patterns is also mentioned.

chunks.text: So it, it has influence in the physical world But, but, but it isn't something that you're going to find, you know, by, by, by, by studying physics And so we've started, we've, we've started to ask, you know, what other kinds of patterns might be interesting for biology And so I'll show you just a couple of quick things This little thing, when you're looking at it, you might think that this is some sort of primitive organism that we found from a pond somewhere If you were to sequence the genome, you would find out that you're very mistaken The genome is Homo sapiens, 100% Homo sapiens, normal Homo sapiens We call these anthrobots They're self constructing little biobots that, that are made from adult human tracheal epithelial cells They are not embryonic There's no embryonic tissue here They don't resemble any stage of normal human development They are what your cells do when liberated from the rest of your body and given a chance to have a new life The patient that donated these may or may not be alive, but these guys have rebooted their multicellularity They do some cool stuff They have novel behaviors which we can arrange in ethograms, like we do for animals Half their genome is expressed differently than what they were doing when they were part of the tissue inside the patient They have cool properties like they will heal your neural wounds
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the creation of 'anthrobots', self-constructing biobots made from adult human tracheal epithelial cells. These cells, when separated from the body, exhibit novel behaviors and properties, including the ability to heal neural wounds. The anthrobots do not resemble any stage of normal human development and express half their genome differently than when they were part of the tissue inside the patient.

chunks.text: So if you make a big scratch through this neural tissue in vitro, they'll sit here in this biobot cluster and they'll heal it And you can see here, they'll And who would have known, who would have known that your tracheal cells can do this And we've done this with, with frog embryos too These are xenobots, which are made from frog skin cells, from embryonic epithelial cells They don't have the ability to reproduce the way normal frogs do, but they've figured out something different This is basically von Neumann's dream of a robot that finds material and makes copies of itself If you provide them with loose epithelial cells, they will push them together into little piles and they then sort of polish the little piles The little piles mature into the next generation of xenobots And guess what that does It does the same thing It makes the next generation and the next None of this existed before in evolution There's been no evolutionary pressure to be a good xenobot or to be a good anthrobot And so now we're confronted with some, with two options in order to try to deal with these novel, novel forms, behaviors and other patterns that, that are not directly selected for by evolution We can say they're emergent, which basically just means that they're surprising to us We can catalog them and when we come across them, well, there they are We find emergent things I don't really like it I like it allows you to have a sparse ontology, but it's kind of a mysterious position I don't like just saying that Well, it's a fact that holds in the physical world
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the creation and behavior of xenobots, which are bio-robots made from frog skin cells. These xenobots have the ability to self-replicate in a novel way not seen in normal evolution, presenting a new form of behavior that is not directly selected for by evolution. The speaker also debates the concept of emergent behaviors, expressing a dislike for the term.

chunks.text: Well, it's a fact that holds in the physical world And, and that's that I prefer what I think is a more optimistic version, which is to say, much like the mathematicians is probably an ordered space of these things and we should have a research agenda to systematically investigate them And that the things that we're making, such as xenobots, anthrobots, various chimeras are, and some other crazy stuff such as minimal algorithms, are actually vehicles They're exploration vehicles that you can use to look for patterns in the latent space of possibilities and, and understand how those patterns come into the physical world and under what circumstances
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the creation and use of xenobots, anthrobots, chimeras, and minimal algorithms as exploration vehicles. These are used to investigate patterns in the latent space of possibilities and understand how these patterns manifest in the physical world.

chunks.text: So, so, so, so, so this is, this is my current hypothesis And certainly other people have, have put out versions of this in the past But the idea is that I think we now have actual tools that we can begin to, to study this and to figure out why it is that the frog genome doesn't just point to frog morphologies, but actually it knows how to make many different things that it pulls down And so what I think are, is that the Platonic space doesn't just contain things that mathematicians like, such as facts about prime numbers and such, but also things that we would recognize as kinds of minds, in other words, behavioral patterns and capabilities And what we make when we make, when, when we perceive, produce embryos, xenobots, computers, pretty much anything You're not really making these kinds of things What you're doing is making pointers that allow the ingression of specific patterns from that space into the physical world And our job is to understand the relationship between the pointers and the thing they bring down And okay, I'm going to stop because I already run way out of time
chunks.content_summary: The speaker hypothesizes that the genome, such as that of a frog, is not limited to creating specific morphologies but can produce a variety of forms. This is linked to the concept of Platonic space, which is believed to contain not only mathematical facts but also behavioral patterns and capabilities. The creation of things like embryos, xenobots, and computers is seen as making pointers that allow specific patterns from the Platonic space to manifest in the physical world.

chunks.text: But just to point out that natural living things are a tiny corner of the pot possible space of beings because any combination of evolved material, engineered material and software is some kind of a system that's going to pull down interesting patterns from the space that we are very bad at predicting Okay, we cannot, we really, we do not know what, when these things come, they come in extremely minimal forms It doesn't take much You know, we found crazy capabilities in classical sorting algorithms, things like bubble sort, which have been studied, you know, for decades We can talk about that And I think, you know, basically what Magritte was trying to tell us here when he said, this is not a pipe, is that when When people say, I know what it is, I've built it, I I put I built it with my own hands I I chose the material
chunks.content_summary: The speaker discusses the complexity and unpredictability of systems that combine evolved and engineered materials with software. They mention the surprising capabilities found in simple sorting algorithms like bubble sort and reference Magritte's philosophy to emphasize the difficulty in fully understanding or predicting such systems.

chunks.text: So I know what this is and I know what it can do I think we have to be extremely careful because I don't think anything is exactly what What the algorithm or the materials say it is That I don't think that's true for For humans in terms of the laws of biochemistry, and I don't think it's true for machines because of the formal limitations of the algorithms that they're supposedly running That's it Here's just the summary of these ideas We now have a research agenda for all of this stuff I'd just like to thank the people who did all the work These are the postdocs and the students in my group, and we have lots of collaborators And I have to do a disclosure There are three companies that I'm involved with Thank you
chunks.content_summary: The speaker, Michael Levin, discusses the limitations of both biochemical laws in humans and formal algorithms in machines, expressing a need for caution in understanding their capabilities. He also acknowledges the contributions of his research team and discloses his involvement with three companies.
